I personally believe Cain married his sister.
 
 WOOOOOOOAH!!! Wait a minute before you start shouting Incest here, people.
 
 First of all, I believe God just created Adam and Eve and let them multiply on their own. If God created just two beforehand and told them to multiply, I can't see why he would make more. I think he left it to them after that.
 
 Second, I don't think it was lawfully wrong right then to marry your sister. The laws weren't introduced then, and I think that was the only way to reproduce without any deformed chromosomes yet available. Joseph married an Egyptian, Abraham did the same and so on. After the law was introduced those things weren't prohibited and nobody condemned them for doing wrong. Both were prohibited by law, but the law wasn't established yet. So I don't think there would be a sin or contradiction here.
 
 Fourth, I can't see God making an extra women especially for Cain right after he had declared him a fugitive and a vagabond upon the face of the earth. It doesn't make sense to me.
 
 I'm open to debate on this, if anyone has any different views.

 The reader must understand that the Torah contains a great variety of material: laws, narratives, history, folk tales, songs, proverbial sayings, poetry, and, in the early parts of Genesis, myths and legends.
 
 Contemporary readers are often put off because they have been exposed to a method of biblical interpretation which understands the text in a literal way. Thus, if Genesis says that God created woman out of the rib of man, or tells of a serpent speaking, or of ancient man living several hundred years, the literalist interprets the story to mean precisely what the words convey. The contemporary reader familiar with the history and nature of the text will have to remember that a literal understanding of the Torah may lead to grave misconceptions. -- The Torah, A Modern Commentary, Union of American Hebrew Congregations Pub., New York

From wikipedia as the edit post feature seems to be playing up for some reason.
 
The passage in Genesis 1:27 - "So God created man in his own image, in the image of God created he him; male and female created he them" (before describing a mate being made of Adam's rib and being called Eve in Genesis 2:22) is sometimes believed to be an indication that Adam had a wife before Eve.
 
 A medieval reference to Lilith as the first wife of Adam is the anonymous The Alphabet of Ben-Sira, written sometime between the 8th and 11th centuries. Lilith is described as refusing to assume a subservient role to Adam during sexual intercourse and so deserting him ("She said, 'I will not lie below,' and he said, 'I will not lie beneath you, but only on top. For you are fit only to be in the bottom position, while I am to be the superior one.'"). Lilith promptly uttered the name of God, took to the air, and left the Garden, settling on the Red Sea coast. As a side note, this places Lilith in a unique position, for she left the Garden of her own accord and before the Fall of Man, and so is untouched by the Tree of Knowledge. However, according to legend, she also knows the "true name of God". To know the true name of God is to have power over him, this story is similar to Isis and the Secret Name of Ra.
 
 Lilith then went on to mate with Asmodai and various other demons she found beside the Red Sea, creating countless lilin. Adam urged God to bring Lilith back, so three angels were dispatched after her. When the angels, Senoy, Sansenoy, and Semangelof, made threats to kill one hundred of Lilith's demonic children for each day she stayed away, she countered that she would prey eternally upon the descendants of Adam and Eve, who could be saved only by invoking the names of the three angels. She did not return to Adam.
 
 The background and purpose of The Alphabet of Ben-Sira is unclear. It is a collection of stories about heroes of the Bible and Talmud, it may have been a collection of folk-tales, a refutation of Christian, Karaite, or other separatist movements; its content seems so offensive to contemporary Jews that it was even suggested that it could be an anti-Jewish satire [4], although, in any case, the text was accepted by the Jewish mystics of medieval Germany.
 
 The Alphabet of Ben-Sira is the earliest surviving source of the story, and the conception that Lilith was Adam's first wife became only widely known with the 17th century Lexicon Talmudicum of Johannes Buxtorf.
 
 In the late 19th century, the Scottish Christian author George MacDonald incorporated the story of Lilith as Adam's first wife and predator of Eve's children into a mythopoeic fantasy novel in the Romantic style.
 
 The role of Lilith as Adam's faithless wife has parallels with the ideas about Eve herself in the Unification theology of Sun Myung Moon.

 You might find the following to be of interest...
 
 The reader must understand that the Torah contains a great variety of material: laws, narratives, history, folk tales, songs, proverbial sayings, poetry, and, in the early parts of Genesis, myths and legends. Contemporary readers are often put off because they have been exposed to a method of biblical interpretation which understands the text in a literal way. Thus, if Genesis says that God created woman out of the rib of man, or tells of a serpent speaking, or of ancient man living several hundred years, the literalist interprets the story to mean precisely what the words convey. The contemporary reader familiar with the history and nature of the text will have to remember that a literal understanding of the Torah may lead to grave misconceptions. -- The Torah, A Modern Commentary, Union of American Hebrew Congregations Pub., New York
 
 and...
 
 Doubts that the Torah was a book set down by one author, Moses, developed some centuries ago...The early critics noted the differential use of the names of God in various parts of the Torah, the discrepancies of certain accounts and figures, and different literary styles. Later scholars further analyzed the text so that they could discern many authors and editors...
 
 The theory which continues to command general scholarly adherence is called the Documentary Hypothesis ...In substance it says that there are four major sources or documents (called J, E, P, and D), the combination of which during the fifth century BCE resulted in the creation of a single book, the Torah, which was declared a sacred text by official canonization about the year 400. - The Torah - A Modern Commentary, Edited by W. Gunther Plaut, Union of American Hebrew Congregations Pub.
 
 And...
 
 The anonymous authors of the Torah's legislation were certain that the laws they proposed were not of their invention but were derivable from Mosaic principles. - Etz Hayim - Torah and Commentary, The Rabbinical Assembly of the United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism, JPS Pub.

What do you do when people don't accept the news that you bring - christianity's past has shown us that it tries to make the best of a bad situation by coming back a second time and adapting pagan festivals like christmas and easter to a more worthy cause. Does this mean that jesus had a chocolate egg laying rabbit or has there been some confusion around certain festivals. At no point did anyone seek to deceive people, things may have just been rephrased in such a way to emphasise some aspects over others.
 
 
 
 

 I am not a Jew.........................
 
 
 am I?
 
 Jewish traditions are quite different from Southern Baptists'. I believe Jesus was God, I believe many traditions and laws were rendered obsolete and unnecessary when Jesus died. Jews believe the Jesus was not the Messiah, they do not believe Laws are no longer in effect and all sorts of things that don't agree with my type of Christianity. I didn't know they didn't think the Devil was a fallen angel, and I can't see the logic behind that.
You must recognise that the religion on which your faith/sect/denomination is based is based on the previous beleifs of another. Jesus was most certainly jewish and unless contradicted then surely the older jewish traditions apply (there was a lot of of greek and roman mythology sneaking into various beliefs, basically due to the same reason that Eostre somehow has they celebration remembered every year coinciding when 'some dead guy escaped hell'). Surely the important thing is to look for outside influences into the traditional jewwish beleifs - you can't quite get away with replacing Satan with Hades without good reason. 
 
 People in antiquity and even now have evidence that whilst he was a mean S.O.B Satan was still in service of God as a kind of celestial devil's advocate. I can't see how you can justify a God sending a flood or angel of death to kill a decent proportion of the population whilst saying than an angel coming to test your faith is unfair. I can see how an Angel pitched as the adversary to mankind could be reimagined as the great enemy. By defying Satan you are proving your worth to God, surely its pride though to think you have defied a opponent that God himself could not deal with rather than passing a test the God has set.
 
 Look at the case of abortion and gay marraige, would you consider youself the bad guy if you were the one to spread the news about the risks of such behaviours? You would be going against the majority opinion there yet when an angel is designed to do the same thing to you its considered evil. An action can only be wrong once it is carried out, otherwise it exists purely theorectically.
 
 Any faith left untested is worthless in God's eyes is more or less the motto of the Adversary. Fail and you may suffer eternal damnation (or at least forever away from the grace of the Lord), hold firm and you will be rewarded - yet clearly the obstical itself is not responsible for your sucess or failure. Just You.

An action can only be wrong once it is carried out, otherwise it exists purely theorectically.

 
 That is true, but if it is an order from God, than an angel should do whatever he's told, though the whole angel thing can start a new topic.
 
 
Any faith left untested is worthless in God's eyes is more or less the motto of the Adversary. Fail and you may suffer eternal damnation (or at least forever away from the grace of the Lord), hold firm and you will be rewarded - yet clearly the obstical itself is not responsible for your sucess or failure.  Faith untested does not make it meaningless to God. A dying person may have enough faith to convert before he dies and he'll most likely have no real tests to face. Faith can move mountains, as the scriptures teach us, and faith in God will hold us steady. God will help us through them, we just have to ask him. That's what I've had to do before when I faced different temptations, and I succeeded. If I didn't, more often than not I gave into them.
Orion

I don't understand why you're saying this, Jesus quoted these things, you said it probably wasn't him who said them. I asked who it was, what does who wrote it have to do with it?

 
 We don't know what Jesus said. What we have are statements attributed to Jesus by his later followers most of whom almost certainly never knew him and who were not eyewitnesses to his ministry. What we can surmise is that either 1) Jesus was illiterate, or 2) he didn't bother to write anything down given that the 'end times' were imminent. Part of the problem faced by contemporary biblical scholars is to determine what it was that Jesus actually said. 
 
 
By Southern Baptist belief says the Jesus was Jewish, and when he did, Jewish traditions were rendered obsolete. There is not contradiction or error.

 
 I assume here that you mean 'died'. In any case, rest assured that Jewish beliefs and traditions have not been rendered obsolete. I suggest further that a dose of religious tolerance wouldn't kill you.

Matthew, Mark, Luke and John wrote the gospels and only Luke was not directly acquainted with Jesus. The only reason I can see that biblical scholars try to determine what Jesus actually said is because they want skepticize and discredit him.  Jewish traditions and beliefs are still practiced, I know. But many of them are not necessary. Not wrong, but not necessary. I would not tolerate a Jew who did not believe in Christ anymore than a Jew would welcome a New Testament gospel being read aloud in his church. Religious tolerance could excuse any bad behavior, and the more we tolerate, the less meaning there is in our rules or morals; and the more we tolerate, the less careful we are about our morals. It's happened to me and my family before, not Jewish things, but tolerating little things that didn't seem would kill us. I don't care that Jews don't eat Pigs, and I could care less about them celebrating certain holidays. But I would not celebrate Hanakuh day, and I would not take part in the ceremonies they perform in the idea that Moses or Elijah will return proceeding with Jesus.
 
 Religious tolerance, in the idea you mention, is extremely dangerous. Please don't say such a thing like to me again. I really take offense to such a statement.

 I looked into the Mark that wrote the gospel according to Mark, and he was a different person. He was related to Peter, and he got most of his info from him. It's not so illogical to suppose it was written that long after Christ's death.

 By the way, Orion, I didn't take offense to religious tolerance lightly simply for the fact that many men, even Christians, fall back into sin because they chose to "tolerate" certain things. They didn't even have to be Jewish stuff. The church sermon just today spoke of men just like that who had decided to tolerate sinful things. Mostly for the fact that a little wouldn't hurt them, and now it is hurting them, badly. Religious tolerance just makes the morals and beliefs you live by meaningless, because after a time of 'tolerance' you slide back into what you used to believe intolerable. I don't want that to happen to me, and I hardly want anyone asking me to, in anyway, shape or form in any case at all.
 
 I don't hate you, Orion. But please don't say such a thing again. Kill me or not, that sort of thing is dangerous. I have enough trouble struggling with myself about that without someone else encouraging that.

 Concerning the four Gospels which alone are uncontroverted in the Church of God under heaven, I have learned by tradition that the Gospel according to Matthew, who was at one time a publican and afterwards an Apostle of Jesus Christ, was written first; and that he composed it in the Hebrew tongue and published it for the converts from Judaism. The second written was that according to Mark, who wrote it according to the instruction of Peter, who, in his General Epistle, acknowledged him as a son, saying, "The church that is in Babylon, elect together with you, saluteth you; and so doth Mark my son." And third, was that according to Luke, the Gospel commended by Paul, which he composed for the converts from the Gentiles. Last of all, that according to John. - Origen
